Posts.Content: DoreenF wrote: Oh man ... My good arm and hand are so sore - I've been having some rib pain and had a bone scan and chest xray about a week ago - chest xray showed summation density and nodule on my lung - so my doctor ordered a CT scan w/ contrast. My veins in my right arm do not show very well - and even getting blood tests is sometimes a challenge. For the CT w/ contrast there's no food or drink 4 hours before the test. My test was scheduled for 2:15 - there was an emergency and I got bumped ... so by the time I got in the CT room and they were trying to do the IV it was after 3 - I think around 3:30 ... the nurse was having trouble finding my veins ... tried my inner elbow area - then my hand - blew my vein there ... then warmed me up w/ hot blankets ... they finally brought in another nurse who does the PIC lines and difficult IVs - she tried a few times - and then went to get her ultrasound - even with the ultrasound (several attempts) they couldn't get the IV setup ... they called my doctor - got agreement to do the CT without contrast - and tried one last time - on the backside of my hand - and still could not get the IV started. They ended up doing the CT without contrast ... I sure hope I don't have to go through that again. They told me that the pictures were very clear and felt that the contrast was not necessary ... I am anxious about the results (who wouldn't be - the waiting for test results is always filled with anxiety). I feel like a pin cushion .. my arm and hand hurt - but .. the good news is they totally understood what lymphedema is and not once did anyone suggest trying my left arm instead - they knew and respected that it was off limits. I hope that I don't have to go through that torture again ... or that I can find a way to get my veins to cooperate more on my right arm ... esp when I have to not have liquid for hours before they want blood ... or an IV. I also hope to have an answer re: the rib pain and the nodule they saw on the chest xray explained - and nothing to worry about very very soon.... Do you have any suggestions for making my veins on my good arm cooperate ??? the nurses today suggested lifting weights and building more muscle on my good arm ... Doreen "Cancer May Leave Your Body, but It Never Leaves Your Life" - Lance Armstrong Foundation Manifesto. Dx 4/18/2005, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2007 05:06PM - edited Dec 3, 2007 09:24PM by DoreenF Hi Lisa -  sorry you've had to join us here ...  lymphedema is such a persistent thing -   we all seem to find what works for us (or not) and sometimes have to get pretty creative to get persistent swell spots of problematic areas under control.   My lymphedema (early stage) began in July of 2005 -  I use a night sleeve (jovipak) and day sleeve/gauntlet (bio-concepts) every day.  I can sometimes go without my day sleeve for a few hours in the evening - but I really notice a heaviness and tiredness in my arm when I'm not wearing my sleeve - so I don't do that very often -  I've read about others here who can go for a day or so without using their sleeve/glove  ... so ...  once your LE is under control and you know how to get it back in control yourself -  you can experiment a bit and see what works for you. changes in the weather affect my LE -  hot, humid,  air pressure changes , altitude changes affect my LE (if I drive over a mountain range) -  I spent a week by the ocean for vacation and that was heavenly -  my LE did not bother me at all ...  I certainly noticed the difference when I got back home...      gentle hugs,   Doreen

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2007 10:18PM - edited Nov 28, 2007 10:18PM by DoreenF I think the bottom line is we really need to listen to our bodies ... and in particular to the side of the body our "procedures" were on ...   and stop doing what we're doing if we feel any sign of tiredness.   Chloe - others here have developed lymphedema after crocheting or knitting  - so it doesn't have to be an activity associated with weight ...    I really hope that you do not have lymphedema  - and that your specialist will be able to help you get your arm feeling better again quickly.   My arm feels really weak - and tired when I don't wear my compression garments  -  I notice it within about 10 minutes ...    Gentle hugs, Doreen
Posts.Title: Raking leaves Chloe68 righarm06

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2007 09:57AM DoreenF wrote: Sonnebe: I think the rationale is very similar to why we have a lumpectomy or mastectomy to remove the cancer from our breasts ...   if cancer is found in the lymph nodes the doctors want to remove as many lymph nodes as they need to to remove as much of the cancer cells as they can ...   they do not want to bet that the chemo and/or radiation will remove any/all traces of cancer cells - they want to remove as much as they can surgically to ensure you have the best prognosis going forward.   I'm not a medical professional - but this seems to be the rationale from everything I've seen. Doreen
Posts.Title: removing lymphe nodes sonnebe London-Virginia

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2008 01:38PM DoreenF wrote: Hi Ckay - I'm also really sorry you had to join our club - but glad you found this site ...  you will find it to be a tremendous source of information and support.   Re: which surgery is best -  from the info you've shared it sounds like you would be a candidate for lumpectomy followed by rads - my surgeon explained to me that a lumpectomy followed by rads has similar statistics for local recurrance as having a mastectomy.   I second and third the opinions to ask the surgeon why they are recommeding a mastectomy - and seek a second opinion - even if you feel comfortable with the decision.   I'd also ask about the node biopsy and find out about the surgeon's experience doing sential node biopsies.   For understanding your personal risk of recurrance -  if you have IDC or ILC - early stage   - and your tumor is estrogen positive -  you'll want to see if you can have the Oncotype DX test done -  it will give you a recurrance score based on analyzing genes within the tumor sample (I think its' 22 - but might be 26 genes).  I used the results of this test to help me make a decision about chemotherapy.   There are new study results showing that the Oncotype DX test is useful even if there are positive nodes ...    I hope this helps ... please keep us posted and let us know if you have any questions or concerns that we can help with. Hugs, Doreen

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2007 03:01PM DoreenF wrote: Hi:  Just wanted to add to the discussion -  this is a really hard and personal decision to make.   I was diagnosed in April of 2005 and the Oncotype DX test was very new at that time.   My surgeon recommended the test -  my score came back a 19 -  at the low end of the intermediate group.  My oncologist was just going to an oncology conference and came back from that conference jazzed up about the oncotype test.   I had several long discussions with him about the risks and benefits from chemo  for my situation.   He was very clear that the decision was mine and he'd support what I choose.   After lots of hard thinking I chose to decline chemo -  my treatment was lumpectomy,  hysterectomy w/ removal of my ovaries (other factors strongly affected that decision),  radiation and Arimidex for my hormone therapy.    I'm 2 1/2 years out now and doing well.  My doctors all tell me I have an excellent prognosis.   My tumor was 9mm IDC, no lymph node involvement,   ER+++, PR+++,  Her2neu negative -  grade 2 or 3 (the grade differs from biopsy pathology and lumpectomy pathology - my oncologist says use grade 2 since that's from the lumpectomy and they had a bigger sample to analyze).    There's a trial currently underway -  called the TailorX trial -  they are studying the midrange group -  the scores they are studying include the high end of the low risk group and the low end of the high risk group in addition to the intermediate risk group of Oncotype DX scores.   You might want to consider participating in the study -  it will do followup for up to 20 years -  the intent of the study is to clearly define the Oncotype scores where chemotherapy is truely of benefit  - and those scores where chemotherapy is over-treatment.   I tried to enroll in the study - but it was too far after my lumpectomy - my primary reason for enrolling was to factor my results into the study - and to  have the followup care defined by the study.     There are many many cancer centers participating in the study -   and the chemo protocol is not dictated by the study -   its'  standard of care -  certainly worth checking into with your oncologist -  even if you make the chemo choice yourself it might be possible to be included in the study.   Hugs, Doreen

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2007 08:52PM DoreenF wrote: Hi Dinosm - My first sleeve and glove were from Juzo and they are made from a heavy material and snag very quickly.  I now use a sleeve and glove from bio-concepts  - the material is much lighter and they come in 30 different colors   -  you can see them at this link www.bio-con.com/lymphedema.html many others here use bio-concepts - they are located in Arizona - I learned of them from this site -  Binney and NPat use them -  I'm not sure who else.   They will bill some insurance companies directly -  mine is not one of them so I have to order through a DME  (Durable Medical Equipment).  use the links on the left to see the colors and their measuring charts and order form -  the forms list measurements in inches but I've been told that they will accept measurements in centimeters and millimeters.   Good luck - I hope you get some garments that fit you correctly quickly.  Doreen

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2007 08:54PM DoreenF wrote: I missed your question about the night sleeve vs. wrapping -  I think they do equivalent things - but the night sleeve is sooo much easier than wrapping. The night sleeves are expensive and I've been told that many times insurance will not cover it -   you might have to "fight" to get one -  they are sooo much easier than wrapping though -  so it makes it much easier to be a compliant patient.  Doreen

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2008 01:26PM DoreenF wrote: Oncologists certainly are different - and sometimes I wonder if it's due to how up they are on the latest information available  ...   My cancer was diagnosed 3 years ago and Oncotype was VERY new at that time.   My surgeon ordered the oncotype DX test and I didn't have the results back the first time I saw my oncologist.  However at that visit he stated something like he didn't think the oncotype test results would be very helpful in helping to make a decision about whether to do chemo or not.  The rad onc had already told me that if we used the NCCN guidelines at that time,  chemo was not warranted.  My oncologist told me the decision was mine to make as it was a grey area.  When I got my oncotype DX results back my score was a 19.  My oncologist had just been to a conference the week before and attended several sessions about oncotype DX and he came back from the conference more of a believer ...  he still told me the decision was mine and he'd support which ever decision I made ...  I declined chemo (but had an oopherectomy and hysterectomy - there were other factors involved - not just my breast cancer)  and then went through rads and started on Arimidex.  It's a very hard decision to make ...  I'm really hoping that the TailorX trial results will help to determine the cutoff for where chemo is really of benefit.   Doreen

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2008 10:03PM DoreenF wrote: sandilee -  the grade of my IDC was either a 3 (biopsy) or 2 (lumpectomy) -  I wasn't sure which was correct - my oncologist said to go with the grade from the lumpectomy since there was more tissue there to look at.   My recurrance score from oncotype was a 19 -   at the low end of the intermediate risk group.  Harley - I'm really sorry to hear that your insurance will not cover the oncotype DX  -  I know that genomic health (the maker of oncotype DX) will appeal the insurance decision several times to try to get it covered.  I've seen many examples of their appeals working from women here.  I'd suggest you ask if you can send them a copy of your 2006 tax return ... I currently don't even have all the info I need to work on my 2007 taxes ...  I think that it would be a reasonable request to see if they can work from your 2006 returns - I suspect they are trying to discount the cost of the test for you and would base the cost on your income - if your insurance refuses to pay ...     I hope you can get this straightened out soon ... sorry you're having to worry about this!   Doreen

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2008 01:47PM - edited Aug 4, 2008 01:54PM by DoreenF GJ -  with your oncotype DX score of 16 you are in the low risk of recurrance.  What type of cancer do you have (IDC, ILC) and what are the estrogen, progesterone,  her2/neu characteristics ?  why type of surgery are you planning?  My score was a 19 and I declined chemo - but had a lumpectomy, hysterectomy, radiation treatment and am taking arimidex (hormone therapy).  I'm currently 3 years out from my diagnosis and doing well. Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2008 04:01AM DoreenF wrote: If you have no complications 2-4 weeks should be sufficient time to recover. I had a complete hyster done laproscopically  -   and didn't have any complications -  I felt pretty good after about 3 weeks ...  I needed help for those three weeks though -  my parents came to stay and helped me with stuff around the house - and driving for the first week or  so  (I had my hyster shortly after my bc diagnosis ...)  lots of considerations - but I was having a problem with fibroids  - and choose to have the hyster as it dealt with several problems - the fibroids,  estrogen reduction -   hystersisters.com is a good resource for knowing what you can expect - and has checkpoints for recovery - things to do and not do ... Doreen

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2008 05:05PM DoreenF wrote: Great List !!!  I totally agree that the LE keeps bc in the forefront of our lives ... and affects our daily lifes in a huge way.  Alyjens -  I've been making no-knead bread and it tastes great and is super easy. I've been using recipes from the book "Artisan Bread in 5 Minutes a Day" - the 5 minutes is active time -  clearly you have to shape the dough, let the bread dough rise and bake it!   You can find the basic recipe at the following link if you're interested  www.kare11.com/life/recipes/re...  the authors' blog is http://www.artisanbreadinfive.com they are active on the blog and it's a great read. If you put the bread on parchament paper or a silpat it's much easier to get the bread in the oven (than using a pizza peel or flat cookie sheet w/ cornmeal). I hope this will help you and allow you to enjoy making bread again! Doreen

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2009 05:30PM DoreenF wrote: mjones777 - welcome - that's a good question.  CDT/MLD or the pumps reduce the swelling in your arm -  the compression garments keep the swelling down- so... they should be used in conjunction with each other.  I know how uncomfortable the compression garments can be when it is hot outside  - but the heat can also increase the amount of swelling you have.  Some garment manufacturers use different fabrics -  the ones I use feel lighter and breathe more easily than the first compression garments that I had. Sorry to be the bearer of bad news ... wish there was another solution to this swell condition that we have.   Gentle hugs, Doreen

Posts.Title: ONCODX Score DianeL820 Dodgerick

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2007 04:18PM DoreenF wrote: Hi Diane -  I'm soo sorry to read that you're terrified and not sleeping well at night.  I know it's very scary -   your cancer was found very very early  and your oncotype score is in the low risk of recurrance. was your cancer IDC or ILC ? Do you know what the grade was ?   How old are you?  Generally all of these factors are taken into account.  I was diagnosed with  stage 1 IDC two and a half years ago  at the age of 44 -    my tumor was .9cm ER+++,  PR +++,  Her2-neu negative and no lymph node involvement -  the grade was 2 or 3 (depending on which pathology report -  biospy or tissue from the lumpectomy).  I had the Oncotype DX test done - it was really new at the time -  my Oncotype score was 19.   My oncologist left the decision on whether to do chemo or not to me -  after lots of hard thinking and analysis I chose to decline chemo -  I did have a hysterectomy and removal of my ovaries (other factors involved) and had radiation and am now taking Arimidex. I'm doing well.   If you are interested -  you could choose to consider participating in a trial -   TailorX  -Here's some info about the TailorX trial- you'll notice that the TailorX trial is focused on a broader group of scores -  it spans the high end of the low risk area,  the intermediate risk area, and the low end of the high risk area -  the intent being that they are trying to determine what the cutoff score is for where chemo is truely a benefit - and not overtreatment or undertreatment for a specific case.  the bottom line is that you need to feel comfortable with the treatment you are getting - none of us knows  what our future holds ... we have to make the decisions we feel are the right decisions for ourselves...  as we live with them. "A large number of these women are receiving toxic chemotherapy unnecessarily, and we need a means of identifying them," said Jo Anne Zujewski, M.D., senior investigator in the Clinical Investigation Branch of NCI's Cancer Therapy Evaluation Program. "TAILORx could help change the way we treat breast cancer and improve the quality of patients' lives, helping to better identify women who are likely to benefit from chemotherapy from those who are not." Oncotype DXTM measures the levels of expression of 21 genes (whether they are transcribed into messenger RNA) in breast tumors. This assessment can more precisely estimate a person's risk of recurrence than standard characteristics, such as tumor size and grade. Based on the Oncotype DXTM gene expression analysis, a recurrence score from 0 to 100 is generated; the higher the score, the greater a woman's chance of having a recurrence if treated with hormonal therapy alone. Women will be studied for 10 years, with an additional follow-up of up to 20 years after initial therapies. Based on their recurrence score, women will be assigned to three different treatment groups in the TAILORx study: * Women with a recurrence score higher than 25 will receive chemotherapy plus hormonal therapy (the standard of care) * Women with a recurrence score lower than 11 will receive hormonal therapy alone * Women with a recurrence score of 11 to 25 will be randomly assigned to receive adjuvant hormonal therapy, with or without chemotherapy. TAILORx is designed primarily to evaluate the effect of chemotherapy on those with a recurrence score of 11 to 25. Women in this last group will comprise 4,390 women, or about 44 percent of the study population. Because the degree of benefit of chemotherapy for women with recurrence scores between 11 and 25 is uncertain, TAILORx seeks to determine if the Oncotype DX test will be helpful in future treatment planning for this group." here's a link to a web page which has more information about the TailorX trial  www.cancer.gov/newscenter/pres...  I hope this is helpful,   You also might want to talk to your doctors about anti-anxiety medications and/or sleeping pills.    Many of us rely on medications to help us .... Hugs, Doreen

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2007 11:17AM - edited Oct 9, 2007 11:17AM by DoreenF I have to agree with the advice you've been given here .. I'd definitely get it checked out ...    here's my story -  I was 44 when I had my first mammogram (I kept putting it off and not making time out of a busy schedule...) -  I got called back for compression views - and immediately following the compression views they took me into another room and did an ultrasound - they suspected a cyst and recommended a followup mammogram in 6 months -  I said I wanted to get it checked - so they referred me to a surgeon.  The surgeon did an ultrasound guided biopsy in his office -  he tried to asiprate it but got no fluid - so he switched to a core biopsy ...  he was 90% confident that it was a fibroadenoma  (which is benign) ...   everyone was surprised when the pathology came back Invasive Ductal Carcinoma  ...   I was glad that I hadn't waited and watched for 6 months as recommended. The doctors cannot always know for certain what something is based on looks alone .. the only way to know for certain is with a biopsy.  I'd want to know ASAP for peace of mind.   I hope you'll get a biopsy.  Chance are good that its' benign -  but if its' not - the earlier you can deal with it the better off you are.   Hugs, Doreen

Posts.Content: DoreenF wrote: Last night I was holding my cat ... he freaked and ended up scratching my arm ... very lightly - didn't bleed or ooze clear fluid (lymph) - I'd just taken off my sleeve/glove and had a naked arm ... I washed the area - and put neosporin on the scratches ... and watched them for signs of change - they got redder for a bit - and wider ... but this morning are looking like someone marked on me with a red pen ... I am continuing to watch for changes ... as I know that cat claws are very germy ... Is there anything else I should be doing - besides watching the area for change (redness, ?) and monitoring my temperature ? I really do not want to get an infection ... the scratches are on the inside of my arm near my elbow - which is where my lymphedema is most prevalent ... Thanks for any tips or warnings... Hugs, Doreen "Cancer May Leave Your Body, but It Never Leaves Your Life" - Lance Armstrong Foundation Manifesto. Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2007 07:47PM - edited Oct 4, 2007 07:47PM by DoreenF Hi:  Have any of your doctors talked to you about having the Oncotype DX test done ?  It's for early stage IDC or ILC w/ ER+  cancer  (used to be for node negative only but recently its' been used for node positive as well).  The test looks at the genes within a sample of the tumor and generates a score which indicates if you are low, intermediate or high risk of recurrance (it actually generates a score which falls into those three categories).  You can read more about the oncotype test here  be sure to access the links at the left hand side of the page too. There's also a trial underway called TailorX - they are studying and following women at the high end of the low risk area, the intermediate risk group and women at the low end of the high risk area - to determine what the cutoffs should be for treatment w/ chemo at both the low end and the high end of the oncotype scores.  It's felt that scores in the low risk do not  receive a benefit from chemo - and scores in the high risk area benefit from chemo - but the intermediate risk group is unclear - so most oncs leave the decision for chemo to the patient.   I had this test done in 2005 when I was diagnosed with Stage 1 IDC.  My score was a 19 - the intermediate risk group starts at 17 ...   I had a couple of long discussions with my oncologist - and ultimately decided to skip chemo - with my oncologists agreement.  I factored in my decision to have an oopherectomy and use one of the newer AI's for my hormone therapy.  I  was 44 when I was diagnosed.  I'm now 2 1/2 years out from my diagnosis and I'm doing great.   It's a very tough and personal decision -  you will come to the right decision for you ... I would encourage you to discuss the Oncotype DX test with your doctor and possibly even consider participating in the TailorX trial -  the trial is about followup and coming up with some standard recommendations for the cutoff on where chemo really is beneficial.   Hugs, Doreen

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2008 11:42AM DoreenF wrote: Mdempsey and Shandra - I'm so sorry that you've had to join our club .. but glad that you found us. There's a ton of information and support here.  Fabulous women who understand your feelings and that will help you get through this fight. You are at the part of the journey that I found the most difficult -  you have a cancer diagnosis but don't have all the specifics and don't yet know what is in front of you as far as a treatment plan. It sounds crazy - but once you've got all of the specifics and have a treament plan in place it does get much easier.   I'm not saying you won't have times where you're anxious, scared, angry or any other emotion that you'll experience - just saying it gets easier as you have a plan.  There's a forum here for young women - you might also want to take a look at that if you haven't found that forum yet.   Sending you lots of hugs and support - let us know if you have any questions and don't be shy about expressing your feelings ... this is a safe place to vent!  Hugs, Doreen

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2007 10:04AM - edited Oct 5, 2007 10:04AM by DoreenF Sharon:  I definitely used the Oncotype DX score heavily in my decision to decline chemo.  Re: the ovary removal ...   and instant menopause - that part has been pretty easy for me -   I was having problems with uterine fibroids  and my gyn had been suggesting a hysterectomy for several years ...  I wasn't ready for it before .. but felt it was the right decision after my bc diaganosis which was strongly estrogen and progesterone driven.    My hysterectomy/oopherectomy was done laproscopically - and I had to spend 1 night in the hospital -   recovery was 4-6 weeks - if you're only having the oopherectomy the recovery is much quicker.  There's another website hystersisters.com  which has a ton of information, checkpoints w/  things to do and not do, along with forums for discussion.  I found that site to be a wonderful resourse.   I really had an easy time with the instant menopause - I have hot flashes,  some problems with short term memory and joint aches  -  those got  a bit worse when I started taking arimidex - since that depletes estrogen from other sources in our bodies.   Since you're planning on chemical shutdown of your ovaries it won't be permanent - if the  sideeffects are too much you could decide to simply not go forward with the shots ... it would also give you an idea of what it would be like if you were to have your ovaries removed. Let me know if I can help with any other info.   I'm really sorry you had to join us here -  but glad you found us.  You'll find this site to have a ton of information, support and answers to pretty much any question you can ask. Hugs, Doreen
